choices.text: 35 days and 42 days
21 days and 35 days
28 days and 45 days
35 days and 28 days

questions.text: Which of the following is the correct storage period when phosphate added to acid citrate dextrose (ACD) and when phosphate and adenine together added to ACD: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. 21 days and 35 days

 

Explanation

 

The storage period when adding phosphate alone to ACD would be 21 days and when adding adenine and phosphate together would be 35 days.

 

ACD was developed into CPD (citrate-phosphate-dextrose) version with phosphate added intended to reduce phosphate leakage from red blood cells. It does not improve shelf life appreciably, but patient recovery is improved.

 

CPD with adenine (CPDA-1), which boosted RBC survival by improving ATP synthesis of RBCs to five weeks when combined with plastic bags.

 

CPD, in combination with adenine-mannitol additives such as SAGM, is the current blood bank preservative as of 2012.

 

RBC hemolysis, thus increasing the storage period to 42 days.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Phosphate alone added to ACD allows for a blood storage period of 21 days, while the addition of both phosphate and adenine (as in CPDA-1) extends the storage period to 35 days, reflecting improvements in RBC viability through enhanced ATP synthesis.

questions.text: A 38-year-old civil engineer is working on a construction project in an area recently affected by a devastating earthquake. To prevent future devastation, the local government has amended the building codes. These changes are aimed at ensuring structures in the area can better withstand seismic activity. The engineer reviews the changes to determine the best approach for the new construction project. This modification to the building codes is primarily an example of which phase of disaster management? [INICET NOV 2022]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) Disaster mitigation

 

  • The measures that are taken to prevent disasters from causing emergencies or to lessen the likely effects of emergencies are part of disaster mitigation.
  • Mitigation involves measures designed either to prevent hazards from causing an emergency or to lessen the likely effects of emergencies. In most cases mitigation measures aim to reduce the vulnerability of the system.

 

In Disaster Cycle, the steps involved are –

 

  1. Disaster Impact and Response: it involves search, rescue, first aid of the patients, triaging them according to the severity of their injuries and their likelihood of survival with prompt medical intervention, tagging and identification of dead.
  2. Relief Phase or Disaster Containment by prompt assistance, epidemiological surveillance and disease control, vaccination, nutritional support.
  3. Rehabilitation involves restoration of the pre-disaster conditions. It takes into account assessment and restoration of water supply, food safety and supply, basic sanitation, personal hygiene, vector control.
  4. Disaster Mitigation involves measures aimed at reducing or preventing the hazards from causing any emergency or to dampen the effects of emergencies. It involves flood mitigation works, appropriate land-use planning, improved building codes and reduction or protection of vulnerable population and structures.
  5. Disaster Preparedness is a long-term programme of developmental activities which aims at strengthening the overall capacity and capability of the country to efficiently and effectively manage all the emergencies.  

 

   

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Disaster mitigation involves proactive measures such as improved building codes to reduce the impact of future disasters, aiming to lessen vulnerability and enhance resilience against potential hazards.

questions.text:
A woman has vomiting whenever she eats spicy food. Arrange the sequence of events during vomiting? (INICET MAY 2022)

 

  1. LES is open and UES is closed.
  2. Strong contractions in the stomach.
  3. Inspiration against a closed glottis.
  4. Relaxation of the pyloric sphincter.
  5. LES opens and UES opens.
  6. Reverse peristalsis in the small intestine.
     

LES: Lower esophageal sphincter

 

UES: Upper esophageal sphincter
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 6, 4, 2, 3, 1, 5

 

The correct sequence of events during vomiting is:

 

6. Reverse peristalsis in the small intestine: This begins the vomiting process, moving contents from the ileum towards the stomach.

 

4. Relaxation of the pyloric sphincter: This allows the contents to move from the small intestine into the stomach.

 

2. Strong contractions in the stomach: These contractions help to force the stomach contents upwards.

 

3. Inspiration against a closed glottis: This involves taking a deep breath with the glottis closed, increasing intra-abdominal pressure.

 

1. LES is open and UES is closed: Initially, the LES opens to allow the contents to move into the esophagus, while the UES remains closed.

 

5. LES opens and UES opens: Finally, both sphincters open to allow the contents to be expelled through the mouth.

 

Act of vomiting involves series of movements that takes place in GI tract.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sequence of events in act of vomiting:

 

  1. Beginning of antiperistalsis, which runs from ileum towards the mouth through the intestine, pushing the intestinal contents into the stomach within few minutes. Velocity of the antiperistalsis is about 2 to 3 cm/second
  2. Deep inspiration followed by temporary cessation of breathing
  3. Closure of glottis
  4. Upward and forward movement of larynx and hyoid bone
  5. Elevation of soft palate
  6. Contraction of diaphragm and abdominal muscles with a characteristic jerk, resulting in elevation of intra-abdominal pressure
  7. Compression of the stomach between diaphragm and abdominal wall leading to rise in intragastric pressure
  8. Simultaneous relaxation of lower esophageal sphincter, esophagus and upper esophageal sphincter
  9. Forceful expulsion of gastric contents (vomitus) through esophagus, pharynx and mouth.

choices.text: Dendritic ulcer on a fluorescein dye

questions.text: What is the characteristic feature of a fungal corneal ulcer?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Satellite lesion

 

Satellite lesions are characteristic of fungal ulcer.

 

The signs of a fungal ulcer include:

  • Irregular margins of the ulcer.
  • Presence of satellite lesions surrounding the ulcer.
  • An immune ring (Wesseley) may be seen around the ulcer due to deposition of the immune complexes.
  • Slough is usually dry, with feathery borders surrounded by a yellow line of demarcation.
  • Hypopyon may be present or absent. If present, it is thick, immobile due to the direct invasion of the fungal hyphae into the anterior chamber.
  • Perforation in mycotic ulcer is rare but can occur.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Reverse hypopyon:  "Reverse hypopyon" can form when emulsified silicone oil used during vitreoretinal surgery enters the anterior chamber of the eye. The silicone oil floats in the aqueous to look like a layered hypopyon in the upper portion of the anterior chamber. Silicone Oil in anterior chamber is called hyperoleon.

 

 

Inverted or reverse hypopyon as a result of emulsification into the anterior chamber. Migration of silicon oil into the anterior chamber displaces aqueous inferiorly and results in a density gradient demarcation line.

 

Option B. Dendritic ulcer on fluorescein dye: Caused by herpes zoster and herpes simplex.

 

Caused by herpes zoster and herpes simplex.

 

 

Pseudodendritic ulcer is caused by acanthamoeba.

 

Option C. Ring abscess: Can be seen in recurrent stromal herpes keratitis or acanthamoeba keratitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Satellite lesions around the main ulcer are characteristic of fungal corneal ulcers, along with irregular margins, immune rings, and potentially immobile hypopyon.

questions.text: A female presents with complaints of hearing loss and pulsatile tinnitus. Rinne’s test reveals conductive hearing loss. On otoscopy, a red and bulgy mass behind the intact tympanic membrane is observed. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Glomus tumor

 

Given clinical scenario is suggestive of glomus tumor

 

Glomus tumor

 

It is the most common benign neoplasm of middle ear and is so-named because of its origin from the glomus bodies.

 

The tumor consists of paraganglionic cells derived from the neural crest.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Serous otitis media: Typically presents with an effusion in the middle ear without signs of infection, leading to a dull or amber appearance of the tympanic membrane rather than a red mass.

 

Option C. Chronic otitis media: Characterized by persistent ear infections and can include a perforated tympanic membrane or cholesteatoma, not typically presenting as a red mass.

 

Option D. Otosclerosis: Affects the ossicles, particularly the stapes, and leads to conductive hearing loss. It does not present as a visible mass in the ear canal.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of a red, pulsatile mass behind an intact tympanic membrane in a patient with pulsatile tinnitus and conductive hearing loss is highly suggestive of a glomus tympanicum tumor, requiring detailed imaging for confirmation and planning of appropriate intervention strategies.

questions.text: Which structure is advised to occlude in ligation of splenic artery? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. D

 

Explanation:

 

Structure D will be occluded in order to ligate the splenic artery.

 

Peritoneal ligaments

 

  1. Gastrosplenic ligaments
  2. Splenorenal ligaments / Lienorenal ligaments (Extends from spleen to Left kidney)

 

Contents

 

  1. TAIL of PANCREAS
  2. SPLENIC VESSELS

 

 

 

In the ligation of the splenic artery, the primary objective is to interrupt the blood supply to the spleen. This procedure may be performed for various medical reasons, such as treating splenic artery aneurysms or managing traumatic injuries to the spleen

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Portal Vein: The portal vein is a major blood vessel that carries nutrient-rich, oxygen-poor blood from the digestive organs (stomach, small intestine, large intestine, and spleen) to the liver. It is not advisable to occlude the portal vein during ligation of the splenic artery because doing so would disrupt blood flow to the liver, potentially leading to severe liver dysfunction and complications.

 

Option B. Hepatogastric Ligament: The hepatogastric ligament is a connective tissue structure that attaches the liver to the stomach. It does not play a significant role in the blood supply to the spleen, so occluding it would not achieve the intended goal of interrupting blood flow to the spleen.

 

Option C. Gastrosplenic Ligament: The gastrosplenic ligament connects the greater curvature of the stomach to the spleen. Although it is in close proximity to the spleen, occluding this ligament alone would not effectively disrupt the blood supply to the spleen.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The lienorenal ligament, also known as the splenorenal ligament, is the structure that connects the spleen to the kidney. It contains the splenic artery, which is the primary vessel supplying blood to the spleen. During ligation of the splenic artery, the lienorenal ligament is typically addressed, and the splenic artery within this ligament is occluded, effectively cutting off the blood supply to the spleen.

choices.text: Rifampicin resistance with both KatG and inhA mutation

questions.text: Which of the following is an inclusion criterion for the shorter bedaquiline regimen in the treatment of tuberculosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Rifampicin-resistant but fluoroquinolone-sensitive TB

 

The shorter bedaquiline regimen is specifically designed for treating certain cases of drug-resistant tuberculosis. It is typically indicated in cases of Rifampicin-resistant (RR) tuberculosis or multidrug-resistant (MDR) tuberculosis under certain conditions. This regimen is used when the tuberculosis strain is resistant to Rifampicin, but it remains sensitive to fluoroquinolones.

 

Additionally, in cases where there is resistance to Isoniazid (INH), the shorter regimen can be used if the resistance is due to a mutation in either the KatG or inhA gene, but not both.

 

If both mutations are present, or if the TB is severe or extrapulmonary, the shorter regimen is not recommended.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Extrapulmonary TB like Tubercular meningitis: The shorter bedaquiline regimen is not indicated for extrapulmonary TB, as it is intended for pulmonary TB only. Extrapulmonary TB often requires a longer and more complex treatment regimen.

 

Option B. Rifampicin resistance with both KatG and inhA mutation: This scenario represents a more complex form of MDR-TB where resistance occurs due to mutations in both the KatG and inhA genes. The presence of both mutations generally excludes the use of the shorter regimen, as a longer and more intensive treatment is required.

 

Option C. Rifampicin-sensitive TB: The shorter bedaquiline regimen is not indicated for Rifampicin-sensitive TB. This regimen is specifically designed for drug-resistant cases, particularly those resistant to Rifampicin.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bedaquiline shorter regimen is indicated for the treatment of -

 

  • Rifampicin-resistant TB (FQ sensitive) or MDR TB
  • INH Resistant TB – due to mutation in either inhA or Kat G gene (NOT BOTH)
  • Pulmonary TB

questions.text: A female patient presented with symptomatic urinary symptoms. On laboratory examination, growth of coagulase negative novobiocin-resistant Staphylococcus with >10⁴ colony growth is seen. What is the true statement regarding this? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Consider it as a UTI


The patient has symptomatic urinary symptoms, and the laboratory findings indicate the presence of coagulase-negative, novobiocin-resistant Staphylococcus with a colony count greater than 10⁴. These characteristics point towards a urinary tract infection (UTI) caused by Staphylococcus saprophyticus, which is known to be novobiocin-resistant and commonly implicated in UTIs, particularly in females. Since the patient is symptomatic, it is important to treat this condition as a UTI rather than dismissing or labeling it as contamination.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Take 3 consecutive urine samples: This option is incorrect because taking 3 consecutive urine samples is usually required for parasitic infections, where organisms are intermittently shed in the urine. For bacterial infections like this one, particularly with a significant growth of a specific organism, this is unnecessary.

 

Option B. No treatment required: This is incorrect as the patient is symptomatic. In symptomatic UTIs, especially with a significant colony count of a known pathogenic organism, treatment is essential. Leaving a symptomatic patient without treatment could lead to worsening of symptoms and complications.

 

Option C. It is a contaminated sample: This is incorrect because contamination is typically suggested when there are multiple types of organisms present or a mix of non-pathogenic flora. In this case, the growth of coagulase-negative, novobiocin-resistant Staphylococcus is specific and significant, aligning with clinical symptoms, ruling out contamination.

 

Educational Objective:


When a female patient presents with symptomatic urinary symptoms and lab findings show coagulase-negative, novobiocin-resistant Staphylococcus with significant colony growth, it should be considered as a UTI and treated accordingly.

questions.text: Which of the below is the most preferred investigation for parathyroid adenoma localisation? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Sestamibi SPECT

 

This is the preferred diagnostic tool for identifying parathyroid adenomas. The technique involves the use of a radioactive tracer, typically Technetium-99m sestamibi, which is absorbed by hyperactive parathyroid tissue more than normal tissue. SPECT provides three-dimensional imaging, improving the localization of hyperactive parathyroid glands.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. CT (Computed Tomography): CT scans are not typically the first line of imaging due to the high levels of radiation exposure and the potential need for contrast agents.

 

Option C. Technetium-99m Sestamibi (tech99-Sestamibi) scan: This is a nuclear imaging which uses a gamma camera for imaging.

 

Option D. USG (Ultrasound): Ultrasound is a non-invasive, widely available, and less expensive method to examine the neck for parathyroid adenomas. It is particularly useful in conjunction with Sestamibi scans, as it helps to evaluate the structure of the neck and localize adenomas. However, its effectiveness can be limited by the operator's experience and the patient's anatomy.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

While all these methods can assist in the diagnosis and localization of parathyroid adenomas, Sestamibi SPECT is generally considered the most effective standalone imaging modality due to its high specificity for active parathyroid tissue and its ability to provide detailed spatial resolution. It is particularly valuable in surgical planning to ensure precise removal of the adenoma.

choices.text: Calcium channel blocker

questions.text: For the diagnosis of resistant hypertension, the patient should have uncontrolled hypertension despite taking three antihypertensive drugs. This should include at least one? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Diuretic

 

Resistant hypertension is defined as blood pressure that remains above the target levels despite the use of three antihypertensive agents of different classes, one of which should be a diuretic. This is because diuretics, typically thiazide diuretics, help to reduce blood volume and are effective in lowering blood pressure. Including a diuretic ensures optimal blood pressure control.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Calcium channel blockers: Calcium channel blockers are used but are not specifically required for the diagnosis of resistant hypertension.

 

Option B. Beta blockers: Beta blockers are also commonly used but not specifically required for the definition.

 

Option C. Alpha blockers: Alpha blockers may be used as part of the treatment regimen but are not specifically required.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The diagnostic criteria for resistant hypertension include having blood pressure above target despite taking three drugs, one of which must be a diuretic, OR having controlled blood pressure with four or more drugs. Typically, a thiazide diuretic is used in the setting of hypertension.

choices.text: 11-year-old girl with Tanner stage 1 breasts
14-year-old girl with Tanner stage 1 breasts
13-year-old girl with Tanner stage 5 breasts

questions.text: Which of the following patients would be classified as having primary amenorrhea? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 14-year-old girl with Tanner stage 1 breasts

 

  • Primary amenorrhea is defined as:
    • No menstruation by age 13 in the absence of secondary sexual characteristics.
    • No menstruation by age 15 in the presence of secondary sexual characteristics.
  • In this context:
    • Option A: An 11-year-old girl with Tanner stage 1 breasts would not be classified as having primary amenorrhea since she is not yet 13.
    • Option B: A 14-year-old girl with Tanner stage 1 breasts meets the criteria for primary amenorrhea because she is older than 13 and has no secondary sexual characteristics (Tanner stage 1 breasts).
    • Option C: A 13-year-old girl with Tanner stage 5 breasts is developing normally and does not meet the criteria for primary amenorrhea.
    • Option D: A 12-year-old with Tanner stage 4 breasts is developing normally and does not meet the criteria for primary amenorrhea.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 11-year-old girl with Tanner stage 1 breasts: The girl is too young to be classified as having primary amenorrhea.

 

Option C. 13-year-old girl with Tanner stage 5 breasts: The girl has developed secondary sexual characteristics and is within the normal age range for the onset of menstruation.

 

Option D. 12-year-old with Tanner stage 4 breasts: The girl has developed secondary sexual characteristics and is within the normal age range for the onset of menstruation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Primary amenorrhea is defined as the absence of menstruation by age 13 without secondary sexual characteristics or by age 15 with secondary sexual characteristics.

 

Ref: ACOG Committee opinion menstruation in girls and adolescents (2015), Speroff’s gynecologic endocrinology 7th edition pg401, Dutta’s textbook of gynecology 6th edition pg 450

questions.text: A chronic alcoholic presented with abdominal pain. His amylase and lipase levels were elevated. Which of the following will be seen? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Enzymatic fat necrosis

 

The patient, a chronic alcoholic, presents with abdominal pain and elevated levels of amylase and lipase, which are indicative of pancreatitis. In cases of both acute and chronic pancreatitis, the typical pathological finding is enzymatic fat necrosis. This occurs when pancreatic enzymes, particularly lipase, escape into the surrounding tissues, leading to fat digestion and necrosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Coagulative necrosis: This type of necrosis is typically associated with ischemic injury, such as myocardial infarction, and is characterized by the preservation of cellular outlines.

 

Option C. Caseous necrosis: This type of necrosis is characteristic of tuberculosis infections and some fungal infections. It presents with a cheese-like appearance and is not associated with pancreatitis.

 

Option D. Fibrinoid necrosis:  This type of necrosis is usually seen in immune reactions involving blood vessels, such as in vasculitis or severe hypertension, where immune complexes and fibrin are deposited in vessel walls.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In pancreatitis, especially in chronic alcoholics, the characteristic pathological finding is enzymatic fat necrosis, resulting from the action of pancreatic enzymes on the surrounding fatty tissues.

choices.text: Loud S1 is a common finding
Echo will show diastolic RA/RV collapse

questions.text: A 45-year-old female with a history of chest pain and upper respiratory tract infection, seven days ago, presents with shortness of breath. She has BP of 100/60 mm Hg and a pulse rate of 110/min. Chest x-ray reviews an enlarged heart, which appears like a water bottle. Which of the following is incorrect? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Loud S1 is a common finding

 

The patient is likely suffering from pericardial effusion, possibly progressing to cardiac tamponade, secondary to a recent viral infection. This is suggested by the history of an upper respiratory tract infection, the physical findings, and the characteristic "water bottle" appearance of the heart on the chest x-ray.

 

The incorrect statement is Loud S1 is a common finding. In fact, one of the hallmarks of cardiac tamponade is muffled or distant heart sounds due to the insulating effect of the pericardial fluid, as described in Beck's triad, which includes hypotension, jugular venous distension, and muffled heart sounds.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pulsus Paradoxus is usually seen: This is true. Pulsus paradoxus is a significant drop in blood pressure during inspiration, common in cardiac tamponade.

 

Option B. Pericardiocentesis may be required: This is true. Pericardiocentesis is often necessary to remove the excess fluid and relieve pressure on the heart, especially if the patient is hemodynamically unstable.

 

Option D. Echo will show diastolic RA/RV collapse: This is true. In cardiac tamponade, the pressure from the pericardial fluid prevents the right atrium and right ventricle from expanding during diastole, leading to their collapse. Echocardiography will reveal this diastolic collapse, confirming cardiac tamponade.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cardiac tamponade, muffled heart sounds are a key finding, not a loud S1.

questions.text: Identify the blocked structure. (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Maxillary sinus

 

The image shows a coronal CT scan of the sinuses, where a blocked structure is indicated by the arrow. The blockage appears to be in the maxillary sinus, which is characterized by the presence of an antrochoanal polyp. Antrochoanal polyps originate in the maxillary sinus and extend into the nasal cavity, typically passing through the middle meatus. In this case, the blockage is in the maxillary sinus, as evidenced by the extension of the polyp towards the middle meatus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ethmoid sinus: This is incorrect because the ethmoid sinus is located medially and superiorly to the maxillary sinus and does not match the position of the blockage shown in the image.

  

Option C. Frontal sinus: This is incorrect as the frontal sinus is located above the eyes and towards the forehead, which is not indicated as blocked in the image.

 Option D. Sphenoid sinus: This is incorrect because the sphenoid sinus is located deeper within the skull, behind the ethmoid sinuses, and is not the blocked area shown.

    

Educational Objective:

 

The maxillary sinus can be blocked by an antrochoanal polyp that extends into the nasal cavity through the middle meatus.

choices.text: Rupture of valve
Calcification and fibrosis
Hypertrophy of ventricular wall
Hypertrophy of the atrial wall

questions.text: A 47-year-old female patient with a long-standing history of rheumatic heart disease was admitted to hospital due to severe breathlessness. She died on the 3rd day following admission. The mitral valve shows the following findings on autopsy. What is the cause of these findings? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Calcification and Fibrosis

 

The illustration depicts rheumatic heart disease and mitral stenosis with a fish mouth or buttonhole appearance. Calcification and fibrosis are the causes.

 

RHD is primarily identified by mitral stenosis, for which it is essentially the primary cause, and deforming fibrotic valvular disease.

 

The leaflet thickening, commissural fusion and shortening, and thickening and fusing of the tendinous cords are the three primary anatomic alterations of the mitral valve in chronic RHD.

 

"Fish mouth" or "buttonhole" stenosis are caused by calcification and fibrous bridging over the valvular commissures.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rupture of valve: Not indicated in the image or history provided.

 

Option C. Hypertrophy of ventricular wall: While ventricular wall hypertrophy may occur due to increased workload from valvular heart disease, it is not visible on this image of the valve.

 

Option D. Hypertrophy of the atrial wall: Similar to ventricular hypertrophy, atrial wall hypertrophy may occur in response to increased pressure from stenosed valves but is not the direct cause visible in the valve image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In patients with a history of rheumatic heart disease, the mitral valve often undergoes significant morphological changes due to fibrosis and calcification, leading to stenosis with a characteristic "fish mouth" appearance. Understanding these changes is crucial for diagnosing and managing the progression of the disease.

questions.text: The following image shows which X-ray view?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Towne’s view

 

Based on the image provided, where the X-ray beam is directed from above the skull at an angle and the detector is positioned below the skull, the indicated X-ray view is consistent with the Towne’s view.

 

Towne’s view is an X-ray where the beam is angled at approximately 30 degrees to the orbitomeatal line and directed downward toward the patient's head, which is positioned with the chin lifted. This view is particularly useful for assessing the occipital bone, posterior fossa, and foramen magnum, as well as the mastoid and middle ear structures.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Water's view is an X-ray taken with the patient's head tilted backward so that the X-ray beam is directed perpendicularly to the orbitomeatal line. It's often used to visualize the maxillary sinuses, the orbits, and the nasal cavity.

 

Option B. Caldwell view is performed with the patient’s head positioned such that the X-ray beam is angled at 15-20 degrees to the orbitomeatal line and the central ray is directed towards the nose. This view is used to visualize the frontal sinuses, orbits, and ethmoid sinuses.

 

Option D. Schuller’s view is an X-ray that provides a lateral view of the skull, specifically to evaluate the mastoid air cells and the structure of the temporal bone.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Towne’s view X-ray is used to visualize the occipital bone, posterior fossa, foramen magnum, and mastoid process by positioning the patient with the head tilted upward and the X-ray beam angled approximately 30 degrees to the orbitomeatal line.

questions.text: A 54-year-old male recently underwent Coronary Artery Bypass Grafting (CABG). Within a few days after taking a saphenous vein graft, he complained of pain in the legs, and on examination, he had mild sensory loss in the medial aspect of the leg and foot on the side from where the graft was harvested. What is the nerve likely to be injured? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Saphenous nerve

 

The saphenous nerve is a branch of the femoral nerve that provides sensory innervation to the medial aspect of the leg and foot. During coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG), the saphenous vein is often harvested for use as a graft. Due to its close anatomical relationship with the saphenous nerve, the nerve can be inadvertently injured during the vein harvesting process.

 

Injury to the saphenous nerve typically results in sensory disturbances such as pain, numbness, or tingling in the medial aspect of the leg and foot, which matches the patient's presentation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Superficial peroneal nerve: The superficial peroneal nerve provides sensory innervation to the lateral aspect of the lower leg and dorsum of the foot. Injury to this nerve would cause sensory loss in these areas, not the medial aspect of the leg and foot.

 

Option B. Sural nerve: The sural nerve supplies the lateral aspect of the foot and the posterior lower leg. Injury to the sural nerve would not affect the medial aspect of the leg and foot.

 

Option D. Tibial nerve: The tibial nerve provides motor and sensory innervation to the posterior compartment of the leg and the sole of the foot. Injury to the tibial nerve would affect these areas rather than the medial aspect of the leg and foot.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The saphenous nerve, due to its proximity to the saphenous vein, is at risk of injury during saphenous vein harvesting for CABG, leading to sensory loss in the medial aspect of the leg and foot.

questions.text: Match the following:  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1-d, 2-c, 3-b, 4-a

 

The correct matching of the diseases with their diagnostic techniques is as follows:

 

  1. Leprosy - d. Split skin smear
  2. Tinea capitis - c. KOH wet mount
  3. Contact dermatitis - b. Patch test
  4. Lupus vulgaris - a. Biopsy

 

Other options:

 

The other options provided in the multiple choice (A, B, and C) are incorrect matchings of the diseases and diagnostic techniques.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Each skin condition has a specific diagnostic test:

 

  • Leprosy is diagnosed using a split skin smear, typically from the earlobe.
  • Tinea capitis, a fungal infection, is diagnosed using a KOH wet mount of skin, nail, or hair scrapings.
  • Contact dermatitis is evaluated using a patch test to identify allergens.
  • Lupus vulgaris, a form of cutaneous tuberculosis, is diagnosed through a skin biopsy to look for granulomas.

questions.text: A 45-year-old lady complains of post-coital bleeding. She has a positive pap smear. What is the next line of management? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Colposcopy directed biopsy

 

Explanation:

 

A positive pap smear indicates the presence of some cytological abnormality (such as epithelial or glandular cell abnormalities). The next appropriate step is to perform a colposcopy and directed biopsy. Colposcopy provides a magnified view of the cervix, allowing for the identification and biopsy of abnormal areas. During the colposcopy, scoring systems like Ried’s index or Swede’s score are used to evaluate the severity of the pathology, and cervical biopsy samples are taken from acetowhite areas identified during the procedure.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Cone biopsy (Conization):

 

  • Conization is typically reserved for situations where there is:
    • Unsatisfactory colposcopic findings (where the entire lesion cannot be visualized).
    • Inconsistent findings between colposcopy, cytology, and directed biopsy.
    • Positive endocervical curettage.
    • When biopsy cannot rule out invasive cancer from carcinoma in situ (CIS) or microinvasion.

 

Option C. Repeat pap smear:

 

  • This is not preferred in this scenario as the exact abnormality on the pap smear is not specified. In cases of low-grade squamous intra-epithelial lesion (LSIL) with negative HPV, a repeat pap smear with HPV testing may be advised, but this is not applicable here.

 

Option D. Hysterectomy:

 

  • Hysterectomy is never indicated solely for an abnormal pap smear. It is considered only if the colposcopic-directed biopsy shows:
    • Cervical intraepithelial neoplasia (CIN) associated with other gynecologic problems such as prolapse, fibroids, pelvic inflammatory disease, or endometriosis.
    • Persistent dyskaryotic smear despite treatment.
    • High-grade CIN in elderly women.
    • Patients with poor compliance for follow-up.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Following a positive pap smear indicating abnormal cytology, the next step is to perform a colposcopy and directed biopsy to further evaluate and manage the cervical pathology.

 

Ref: Page no 329, Dc Duttas Textbook of Gynecology 6th edition

choices.text: O2 pressure in inhaled air

questions.text: You are in the operating room and notice the tracing in gray color waveform on this device. What does it indicate? (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Capnography

 

  • Function: Capnography measures the concentration of CO2 in exhaled air over time, producing a waveform called a capnogram.
  • Components: Capnography equipment typically comprises a CO2 sensor, which can be placed in the circuit of a mechanically ventilated patient or near the patient's airway for non-intubated individuals (e.g., during procedural sedation). The CO2 concentration is then plotted over time to produce a waveform.
  • Waveform Analysis: The capnogram is typically divided into four phases:
    • Phase I: Baseline, representing inspired gas, which is ideally CO2-free.
    • Phase II: The expiratory upstroke, representing the beginning of expiration with a mix of dead space and alveolar gas.
    • Phase III: Alveolar plateau, where the CO2 concentration stabilizes, reflecting primarily alveolar gas.
    • Phase 0: Inspiratory downstroke, as the patient begins to inhale again.

 

 

  • End-Tidal CO2 (EtCO2): This is the maximum value of CO2 at the end of expiration, and it provides an estimation of the arterial CO2 concentration, although they may not always be identical due to various physiological and pathological factors.

 

Clinical Applications:

 

  • Confirming correct endotracheal tube placement.
  • Monitoring the quality of cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR). A sudden rise in EtCO2 can indicate return of spontaneous circulation (ROSC).
  • Evaluating a patient's ventilatory status.
  • Monitoring patients during procedural sedation.
  • Detecting conditions like pulmonary embolism, bronchospasm, and hypoventilation, among others.

 

Limitations:

 

  • Factors like changes in cardiac output, changes in alveolar ventilation, and equipment issues can influence the accuracy of capnography.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Airway pressure: Airway pressure monitoring involves measuring the pressure within the airways, typically during mechanical ventilation, but it does not produce a CO2 waveform.

 

Option C. O2 pressure in inhaled air: Measuring the pressure of oxygen in inhaled air is not typically displayed as a capnography waveform.

 

Option D. O2 pressure in exhaled air: Measuring the pressure of oxygen in exhaled air is not typically displayed as a capnography waveform.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Capnography is a crucial monitoring tool in the operating room and other clinical settings, used to measure and display the concentration of CO2 in exhaled air over time, helping to assess ventilation, confirm endotracheal tube placement, and monitor the effectiveness of resuscitation

questions.text: Which of the following tests relies on the principle that prior knowledge of events or activities will influence a suspect's physiological responses? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Brain Mapping

 

Brain mapping is based on the principle that if a suspect has prior knowledge of an event or activity, it will be reflected in their brain wave responses. This technique involves measuring electrical brain wave responses (P300) to familiar stimuli, such as words, phrases, or pictures, presented on a computer screen. The P300 wave is an event-related potential (ERP) component elicited in the process of decision-making and is used to detect the recognition of familiar information. When a suspect recognizes the stimuli related to the event or activity, their brain produces a distinct response that can be measured and analyzed.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Truth Serum: Truth serum refers to drugs used to make a person more likely to divulge truthful information. These drugs work by depressing the central nervous system to the point where the subject is less capable of resisting questioning and less likely to lie. It does not rely on physiological responses to prior knowledge.

 

Option B. Polygraph: The polygraph test measures physiological responses such as heart rate, blood pressure, and skin conductivity to determine if a person is lying. It is based on the theory that deceptive answers will produce physiological changes due to the emotional responses associated with lying, such as fear or anxiety. However, it does not specifically rely on the prior knowledge of events or activities.

 

Option C. Hypnosis: Hypnosis involves putting a subject into a trance-like state where they may be more open to suggestions and potentially recall forgotten details. It does not rely on physiological responses related to prior knowledge and is not primarily used for detecting deception based on prior knowledge of events.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Brain mapping detects recognition of familiar stimuli through brain wave responses, reflecting a suspect's prior knowledge of events or activities

questions.text: Seman's squeeze technique is used for which of the following conditions?( NEET PG 2018 )
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Premature ejaculation

 

Seman's squeeze technique is a behavioral therapy method used to treat premature ejaculation. It involves the man or his partner squeezing the tip of the penis for several seconds right before ejaculation is expected. This helps in delaying ejaculation. The other options do not involve the use of this technique.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Retrograde ejaculation: Retrograde ejaculation refers to the backward flow of semen into the bladder instead of out of the penis.

 

Option B. Erectile dysfunction: Erectile dysfunction is the inability to achieve or maintain an erection suitable for intercourse. 

 

Most successful psychotherapy for erectile dysfunction is dual-sex therapy by Masters and Johnson.

 

Option D. Painful ejaculation: Painful ejaculation is pain felt during or after ejaculation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Seman's squeeze technique is a non-pharmacological method used to delay ejaculation in men with premature ejaculation. Here, when the man gets the feeling of impending ejaculation, the sex is stopped for some time and once excitement has decreased, it is restarted. Hence, it is also known as stop-start technique. Another non-pharmacological treatment includes squeeze technique, where the female partner squeezes the coronal ridge of the glans, when the man gets the feeling of impending ejaculation.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page No 586.

choices.text: It is the meeting point of frontal, parietal, temporal and sphenoid bones.
Blow to the lateral side of the skull injures the marked structure.
Accessory middle meningeal artery lies under this structure.
It corresponds to site of anterolateral fontanelle of fetal skull.

questions.text: Identify the incorrect statement regarding the marked structure: (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Accessory middle meningeal artery lies under this structure.

 

Explanation:

 

The structure marked in the image is the pterion. The main branch of Middle meningeal artery lies under this structure NOT accessory middle meningeal artery. The accessory middle meningeal artery usually arises from the maxillary artery and enters the middle cranial fossa through the foramen ovale or a separate foramen. Its location and presence can vary.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It is the meeting point of frontal, parietal, temporal, and sphenoid bones. Correct: The pterion is indeed the meeting point of these four bones.

 

Option B. Blow to the lateral side of the skull injures the marked structure. Correct: A blow to the pterion can be very dangerous because the middle meningeal artery runs just deep to this area, on the inner side of the skull. If this artery is ruptured due to a fracture at the pterion, it can lead to an epidural hematoma, which is a type of traumatic brain injury.

 

Option D. It corresponds to the site of the anterolateral fontanelle of the fetal skull. Correct: The pterion corresponds to the region of the anterolateral (or sphenoid) fontanelle in the fetal skull. This fontanelle usually closes a few months after birth.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pterion is the junction point of four bones in the skull: the frontal, parietal, temporal, and sphenoid bones. The term "pterion" comes from the Greek word "pteron," meaning "wing," because the pterion is located at the point where the sphenoid bone and the temporal bone form a wing-like shape. The pterion is located just above the zygomatic arch and anterior to the ear. The middle meningeal artery, a branch of the maxillary artery, runs underneath the pterion and is at risk of injury in cases of head trauma.

questions.text: The following finding can be seen in: (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Parvovirus B19 infection

 

The 5th disease, also known as erythema infectiosum, is caused by Parvovirus B19. It is a common childhood viral infection characterized by a "slapped-cheek" rash.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Molluscum contagiosum: This is not correct. Molluscum contagiosum is a viral skin infection caused by the molluscum contagiosum virus. It does not cause the 5th disease.

 

Option C. HFMD (Hand, Foot, and Mouth Disease): HFMD is caused by enteroviruses, primarily Coxsackievirus A16 and Enterovirus 71. It does not cause the 5th disease.

 

Option D. Kawasaki disease: Kawasaki disease is not caused by Parvovirus B19. It is an inflammatory condition of blood vessels, and its etiology is not related to the virus responsible for the 5th disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Recognize the causative agent of the 5th disease (erythema infectiosum) as Parvovirus B19. Understand the clinical manifestations of the 5th disease, including the characteristic "slapped-cheek" rash, and differentiate it from other childhood viral infections such as HFMD and conditions like Kawasaki disease and molluscum contagiosum.

questions.text: Identify the given image:(FMGE Jan 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Central retinal artery occlusion

 

Above image is showing cherry red spot which is seen in central retinal artery occlusion.

 

Central retinal artery occlusion - it occurs due to the blockade of Retinal Artery by thrombus or embolus at lamina cribrosa.

 

Risk factors: old age, atherosclerosis, hypertension, smoking etc.

Symptoms: Sudden painless U/L loss of vision

Signs: Retinal whitening, Cherry red spot

 

DD:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Central retinal vein occlusion:

 

Fundoscopic Signs: Flame-shaped hemorrhages, cotton wool spots, and optic disc swelling. There is no cherry red spot seen in CRVO.

 

Symptoms: Similar to CRAO with sudden, painless vision loss, but CRVO is associated with hemorrhages and more variable vision loss.

 

Management: Includes addressing complications such as macular edema and neovascularization with treatments like intravitreal injections and laser photocoagulation.

 

Option C. Branched retinal artery occlusion:

 

Fundoscopic Signs: Sectoral retinal whitening corresponding to the area of the blocked artery, but not a generalized cherry red spot.

 

Symptoms: Visual field defects in the area served by the affected artery rather than total vision loss.

 

Management: Similar to CRAO but focused on the affected area, with possible treatments including ocular massage and addressing underlying causes like emboli.

 

Option D. Branched retinal vein occlusion:

 

Fundoscopic Signs: Sectoral retinal hemorrhages, venous tortuosity, and possible cotton wool spots in the affected area.

 

Symptoms: Localized visual field defects rather than total vision loss.

 

Management: Involves treating complications such as macular edema and monitoring for neovascularization, often with intravitreal injections and laser therapy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The "cherry red spot" is a hallmark of central retinal artery occlusion (CRAO), which results from the blockage of the retinal artery and leads to retinal ischemia. Immediate management is critical to attempt to restore vision, although the prognosis is generally poor.

questions.text: Nugent score is for diagnosis of? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Bacterial vaginosis


The Nugent score is a microbiological scoring system used for diagnosing bacterial vaginosis (BV). It is based on the examination of a vaginal smear under a microscope to evaluate the presence and quantity of bacterial morphotypes, particularly Lactobacilli, Gardnerella, and Mobiluncus. A high Nugent score indicates a decrease in normal Lactobacilli and an increase in pathogenic bacteria, which is characteristic of bacterial vaginosis. This scoring system provides a more objective and standardized diagnosis compared to clinical criteria.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Trichomoniasis:  is incorrect because trichomoniasis is diagnosed through wet mount microscopy, culture, or molecular tests, which detect Trichomonas vaginalis, not by the Nugent score.

 

Option C. Candidiasis : is incorrect as it refers to yeast infections typically diagnosed by identifying Candida species on wet mount, KOH preparation, or fungal cultures, not using the Nugent score.

 

Option D. Chlamydia: is incorrect since Chlamydia is diagnosed through nucleic acid amplification tests (NAATs), culture, or antigen detection, not by the Nugent scoring system.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Nugent score is used for the diagnosis of bacterial vaginosis. It is a microbiological scoring system where the vaginal smear is analyzed for the number of lactobacilli and abnormal bacteria. The clinical scoring system for bacterial vaginosis is the Amsel's criteria, which includes the whiff test, clue cells, alkaline pH, and whitish discharge.

choices.text: Painless hematuria
Painful hematuria

questions.text: The most consistent and persistent feature of bladder carcinoma is: (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Painless hematuria

 

Bladder tumors classically produce painless hematuria. This is their dominant and sometimes only clinical manifestation. Frequency, urgency, and dysuria occasionally accompany the hematuria.

 

Bladder tumors produce a wide range of clinical features including:

 

  • Painless hematuria - classical feature and may be the only clinical manifestation
  • Irritative urinary symptoms (frequency, urgency, dysuria) - diffuse tumors or tumors at the bladder neck
  • Pyelonephritis or hydronephrosis - when the ureteral orifice is involved
  • Obstructive symptoms, palpable suprapubic mass, or lower extremity edema - late presentation with a large tumor mass
  • Weight loss and/or localized bone pain - metastatic disease

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Painful hematuria: This symptom, while possible, is less common and typically associated with other urological conditions.

 

Option C. Dysuria: Often occurs with more diffuse tumors or when the tumor is located at the bladder neck but is not as consistently observed as hematuria.

 

Option D. Suprapubic mass: Typically, a sign of advanced disease and not a consistent initial symptom.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Painless hematuria is the classical and most persistent feature of bladder carcinoma, often being the initial and sometimes the only symptom observed.

questions.text: What test is not used for testing olfaction? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Arnold stick test

 

The Arnold stick test is not a recognized method for assessing olfaction. The name does not correspond with standard or commonly used olfactory tests, which typically involve the identification or differentiation of specific odors.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Smell Diskettes: These are used in screening tests for olfaction, where reusable diskettes are impregnated with different odorants. Participants are asked to identify scents from a list, often aided by illustrative questionnaires.

Option C. UPSIT: The University of Pennsylvania Smell Identification Test is a widely recognized and comprehensive olfactory test. It is self-administered and involves scratching odor-impregnated booklets to release smells, which the test-taker must then identify.

Option D. CC-SIT: The Cross-Cultural Smell Identification Test, a shorter form of the UPSIT, consists of 12 items and is designed for quick administration, making it practical for use in diverse populations and clinical settings.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tests used for olfaction are as follows:

 

  1. Smell diskettes are used as a screening test for olfaction. Reusable diskettes are used with the application of 8 different odorants. A questionnaire with illustrations is used to score the patient.
  2. University of Pennsylvania Smell Identification Test (UPSIT) is a commercially available, self-administered test used to assess the function of an individual's olfactory system via smell identification. It uses microencapsulated odorants, which are released on scratching standardized odor-impregnated test booklets.
  3. The 12-item version of UPSIT, also known as the Cross-Cultural Smell Identification Test (CC-SIT), is useful for quantifying smell loss when less time is available. This test serves as a means to reliably assess olfactory function in less than 5 minutes.
  4. The Sniffin' Sticks test is a new test of nasal chemosensory performance based on pen-like odor-dispensing devices. Semi-objective assessment of the patient's olfactory performance by means of 3 subtests: threshold test, identification test and discrimination test.

 

Ref - Scott Brown 8th edition, volume 2, Page No. 1233

questions.text: A child has been brought into the emergency department with symptoms of bilious vomiting. Below is an X-ray image of the abdomen: (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Duodenal atresia

 

  • The image provided is a classic radiographic representation known as the "double bubble" sign, indicative of duodenal atresia.
  • This condition is characterized by a congenital absence or complete closure of a portion of the lumen of the duodenum. The "double bubble" sign, seen here, represents two dilated areas separated by a pinched segment: one in the stomach and another in the proximal duodenum. This leads to vomiting, typically bilious because the obstruction is distal to where the bile duct enters the intestine.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Congenital Hypertrophic Pyloric Stenosis (CHPS): This involves the hypertrophy and hyperplasia of the pyloric sphincter muscle, which leads to obstruction and a “single bubble” appearance. While it can cause projectile vomiting, this usually occurs without bile, and the typical radiographic finding is an elongated pyloric channel .

 

Option C. Jejunal Atresia: The typical radiographic finding might include multiple dilated loops of the bowel, with air-fluid levels depending on the level of obstruction, rather than the “double bubble.”

 

Option D. Volvulus: This is a condition in which there is a twisting of the bowel on itself, leading to an obstruction. And does not present with “double bubble sign ”

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The "double bubble" sign on an abdominal X-ray in a neonate with bilious vomiting is highly suggestive of duodenal atresia. This condition requires surgical intervention, and timely diagnosis is crucial to manage potential complications and outcomes effectively.

questions.text: Identify the blue-colored area shown in the image below?(NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Mid-pelvis

 

The true pelvis is divided into 3 planes

 

  1. Plane of Inlet
  2. Plane of Mid cavity (Mid-Pelvis)
  3. Plane of Outlet

 

The Plane of Mid Cavity (Or Mid-Pelvis) is what is shown in the image

 

Pelvic Cavity

 

This has 2 planes

 

  1. Plane of Greatest Dimension: 
    • At the level of S2/3
    • Circular plane; AP diameter = Transverse diameter = 12.5 cm
    • Widest part of pelvis
  2. Plane of Least dimension
    • At the level of S3/4
    • At the level of ischial spine
    • Very important plane CLINICALLY
      1. Narrowest part of pelvis
      2. Internal rotation takes place here
      3. Origin of levator ani
      4. Landmark for pudendal block
      5. When engagement occurs, the head is felt at 0 station, i.e., at this plane
      6. Deep Transverse Arrest occurs here

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Obstetric outlet:

 

  • Refers to the lower part of the pelvic outlet, which is wider than the anatomical outlet.
  • Not shown in the image.

 

Option B. Anatomical outlet:

 

  • Refers to the narrowest part of the pelvic outlet.
  • Not shown in the image.

 

Option C. Pelvic inlet:

 

  • Marks the entrance to the true pelvis.
  • Not shown in the image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The plane of the mid-pelvis (or mid cavity) is a crucial area within the true pelvis, significant for various clinical considerations during labor and delivery.

 

Ref: Page no 92 Textbook of obstetrics by JB Sharma

choices.text: Transverse septum in the proximal vagina
Complete vaginal atresia

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl presents to the OPD with a history of primary amenorrhea and cyclical pain. Perineal examination reveals a bulge protruding from the vagina. Identify the cause of this presentation? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Imperforate hymen

 

Explanation:

 

  •  Primary amenorrhea with cyclical pain is suggestive of an obstructive cause.
  • O/e a bulge seen protruding from the vagina is suggestive of an imperforate hymen.
  • This classically presents as a bluish bulge distending the hymen.
  • The bulge (hematocolpos) is felt along the entire length of the vagina on doing a PR examination
  • Treatment: Cruciate incision and drainage of hamatocolpos is done.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Transverse septum in the proximal vagina: This also will present as primary amenorrhoea with cyclical abdominal pain as the menstrual blood accumulates inside. But on examination, the bulge wont be seen at the introitus as the obstruction is higher up in a proximal or high transverse vaginal septum.

 

Option B. Complete vaginal atresia: In Complete vaginal atresia, also the symptoms of primary amenorrhoea and cyclical abdominal pain will be present, but again the obstruction will be high. There will be hematometra. Local examination will reveal an absent vagina or a bling ending vagina.

 

Option D. Cervical agenesis: In cervical agenesis, again there will be hematometra, I.e. the obstruction is higher up and there will not ne any bulge seen on local exam.

 

Educational Objective

 

Primary amenorrhea with cyclical pain and a bulge protruding from the vagina is indicative of an imperforate hymen, requiring cruciate incision and drainage of hematocolpos.

 

Ref: Page no 450, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology, 6th edition

questions.text: Which is not a product of heme catabolism? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Aminolaevulinic acid

 

Heme catabolism is the process by which the heme portion of hemoglobin is broken down. This process begins with the degradation of heme into biliverdin, which is subsequently reduced to bilirubin. This bilirubin is further processed into conjugated bilirubin, urobilinogen, and stercobilinogen. In addition to these products, heme catabolism also generates carbon monoxide and ferrous ion (Fe²⁺).

 

Aminolaevulinic acid, on the other hand, is not a product of heme catabolism but is instead an important precursor in the synthesis of heme. It is formed in the first step of heme synthesis, where succinyl-CoA and glycine combine under the action of the enzyme aminolaevulinic acid synthase.

 

Therefore, while ferrous ion, biliverdin, and carbon monoxide are products of heme catabolism, aminolaevulinic acid is involved in heme synthesis and not in its breakdown.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ferrous ion: This is indeed a product of heme catabolism, as iron is released during the breakdown of the heme group.

 

Option C. Biliverdin: Biliverdin is one of the direct products of heme degradation, and it is subsequently reduced to bilirubin.

 

Option D. Carbon monoxide: This is another product of heme catabolism, and notably, heme catabolism is the only process in the human body where carbon monoxide is produced endogenously.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Aminolaevulinic acid is a precursor in the synthesis of heme, not a product of its catabolism.

questions.text: An elderly man with diabetic nephropathy presented to the emergency department with palpitations and chest discomfort. The ECG revealed large T-waves. Laboratory tests revealed elevated potassium levels. Which of the following drugs can cause intracellular movement of potassium? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Epinephrine

 

Beta 2 agonists (like Salbutamol and Epinephrine) and Insulin help in the intracellular movement of K+. These drugs therefore can decrease serum potassium levels.

 

The drugs that can be used in the management of acute hyperkalemia are:

 

  • Salbutamol
  • Glucose + Insulin (DOC)
  • Calcium gluconate

 

In case of chronic hyperkalemia, K+ binding resins like Patiromer and Polystyrene sulfonate can be used.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Glucagon: Glucagon primarily works to increase blood glucose levels by promoting glycogenolysis and gluconeogenesis. It does not play a significant role in shifting potassium intracellularly.

 

Option C. Atropine: Atropine is an anticholinergic drug that blocks muscarinic receptors. It is not involved in potassium homeostasis or its intracellular movement.

 

Option D. Lactic acid: Lactic acid does not facilitate the intracellular movement of potassium. In fact, metabolic acidosis (which can be associated with elevated lactic acid levels) tends to cause potassium to move out of cells into the extracellular space, exacerbating hyperkalemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Beta-2 agonists, such as Epinephrine, are effective in promoting the intracellular movement of potassium, thereby reducing serum potassium levels in cases of hyperkalemia.

questions.text: Involvement of PIP, DIP and 1st CMC with sparing of wrist and MCP is seen in: (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Osteoarthritis

 

  • Osteoarthritis characteristically involves distal interphalangeal joint (Heberden’s node), proximal interphalangeal joint (Bouchard’s node), 1st carpometacarpal joint (base of thumb) of hand.

 

 

  • Sparing of wrist and MCP is a feature of Osteoarthritis.
  • Rheumatoid Arthritis spares DIP and involves PIP, MCP and Wrist.
  • Diseases And Usual Joints Affected:

 

 

  • Characteristic Joint involvement in HANDS in various Arthritis:

 

 

 

 

The hand (to diagnose arthritis)

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Rheumatoid arthritis. Commonly Involved Joints (14 joints are used for diagnosis according to 1987 criterion – Right or left side) are Wrist joint, Metacarpophalangeal (MCP) joint, Proximal interphalangeal (PIP) joint, Elbow joint, Knee joint, Ankle joint, and Metatarsophalangeal joint. Less Commonly Involved joints are Upper cervical spine (facet joint) with Atlantoaxial subluxation, Hip joint, Temporomandibular joint, Subtalar and forefoot joints. Usually, DIP is not involved but is involved when swan neck and boutonniere deformity develops. The involvement in late stages is due to the pull of tendons/soft tissues in these deformities. Lumbar Spine is Usually Spared in RA.

 

 

 

Option B. Psoriatic arthropathy. Five patterns of joint involvement are seen: Arthritis of DIP joint, Asymmetrical oligoarthritis, Symmetrical polyarthritis, Axial involvement (spine and sacroiliac joint), and Arthritis mutilans. Nail changes occurs in 90% patients of psoriatic arthritis. Dactylitis, enthesitis and tenosynovitis are also common Shortening of digitis (telescoping), because of underlying osteolysis is characteristic of psoriatic arthritis. Fibrous and bony ankylosis of small joints (greater tendency than RA). Almost any peripheral joint can be involved. Radiological Features includes classical pencil cup deformity of DIP joints.

 

 

Pencil-in-cup deformity

 

Option D. Jaccoud arthropathy. It typically affects MCP joints but can also affect PIP joints of the hand, wrist joint and knee joint. It is a deforming non-erosive arthropathy characterized by ulnar deviation of 2nd-5th fingers with MCP joint subluxation.

 

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Involvement of PIP, DIP and 1st CMC with sparing of wrist and MCP is seen in osteoarthritis.

questions.text: A person was taking an antihypertensive drug and continued taking it despite developing constipation, dry mouth, and dizziness. He was taking it regularly but forgot to take it during a trip abroad and has now developed a hypertensive emergency. Which antihypertensive was he likely taking? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Clonidine

 

Clonidine is an alpha-2 adrenergic agonist used in the management of hypertension. One of the common side effects of Clonidine includes dry mouth, constipation, and dizziness, which matches the symptoms described in this case. Additionally, a significant risk associated with Clonidine is the potential for rebound hypertension if the medication is suddenly discontinued, as can happen if a dose is missed. This rebound effect occurs because the body's sympathetic nervous system experiences a sudden surge in activity once the inhibitory effects of Clonidine are removed, leading to a hypertensive emergency, as seen in this patient.

 

Remember – Clonidine is safe in Pregnancy 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Amlodipine: Amlodipine is a calcium channel blocker used for hypertension but does not typically cause rebound hypertension. Its side effects more commonly include peripheral edema rather than the symptoms described here.

 

Option C. Lisinopril: Lisinopril is an ACE inhibitor that does not cause the described side effects of dry mouth, dizziness, and constipation. Additionally, sudden discontinuation of Lisinopril does not lead to a hypertensive emergency.

 

Option D. Telmisartan: Telmisartan is an angiotensin II receptor blocker (ARB). It generally does not cause dry mouth, constipation, or dizziness, and discontinuation does not lead to rebound hypertension.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Clonidine is an antihypertensive medication that can cause dry mouth, constipation, and dizziness, and sudden discontinuation can lead to rebound hypertension, making it crucial for patients to maintain consistent dosing.

choices.text: A, B and D are correct

questions.text:
Which of these is/are included as a part of primary survey in trauma? (multiple correct combinations) (INICET MAY 2024)

 

A. Endotracheal intubation
B. Chest X-ray
C. Plain CT
D. ICD insertion
questions.solution:
Ans. C) A, B and D are correct

 

The primary survey in trauma is a critical initial assessment conducted to identify and manage life-threatening conditions. It follows the ABCDE approach (Airway, Breathing, Circulation, Disability, and Exposure). The focus is on stabilizing the patient, and only essential interventions are performed during this phase.

 

Option A. Endotracheal Intubation: This is part of airway management in an unstable trauma patient. If the airway is compromised or there is a risk of airway obstruction, endotracheal (ET) intubation is performed immediately to secure the airway.

 

Option B. Chest X-ray: Although a chest X-ray is considered an adjunct to the primary survey, it is often done bedside in the trauma room as part of the initial assessment of breathing and circulation. It is particularly useful for identifying conditions like pneumothorax, hemothorax, or other thoracic injuries that require immediate attention.

 

Option D. ICD Insertion: Intercostal Drain (ICD) insertion is a bedside procedure that can be part of the primary survey if there is a massive pneumothorax or hemothorax. In cases of tension pneumothorax, an immediate needle decompression is performed, followed by ICD insertion, which is critical for patient survival.

 

Other Option:

 

Option C. Plain CT: This is not included in the primary survey. CT scans are generally reserved for stable patients as they require the patient to be transported to the radiology department, which is not feasible or safe in an unstable trauma patient.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the primary survey of a trauma patient, life-saving interventions like ET intubation, bedside chest X-ray, and ICD insertion are performed to stabilize the patient. A CT scan is not part of this immediate assessment and is reserved for stable patients.

questions.text: Parthenogenesis is seen in which of the following worm?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Strongyloides stercoralis

 

Parthenogenesis is a form of asexual reproduction where the female organism is capable of producing offspring without the need for fertilization by a male. In the case of parasitic worms, this phenomenon is specifically seen in Strongyloides stercoralis.

 

Reference Paragraph Explanation:

 

  1. Strongyloides stercoralis: Strongyloides stercoralis is unique among the nematodes because it can reproduce through parthenogenesis. This means that the female worms can produce fertile eggs without mating with a male. In the human host, only female Strongyloides worms are found in the intestine, and they are capable of producing eggs or larvae without male fertilization.
  2. Oviparous, Viviparous, and Oviviparous Nematodes:
    • Oviparous: These worms lay eggs which then develop outside the female’s body. Examples include Ascaris and Trichuris.
    • Viviparous: These worms give birth to live larvae. Examples include some species of Dracunculus and Wuchereria.
    • Oviviparous: These worms lay eggs that hatch immediately as they are laid, producing larvae. Strongyloides stercoralis is an example, as the eggs hatch into larvae almost immediately after being laid.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Trichuris trichura: This worm is oviparous, meaning it lays eggs that develop and hatch outside the female’s body. It does not reproduce via parthenogenesis.

 

Option C. Ancylostoma duodenale: This is also an oviparous worm. It lays eggs that develop in the external environment.

 

Option D. Enterobius vermicularis: Commonly known as pinworm, it is also oviparous, laying eggs that hatch outside the body. It does not reproduce via parthenogenesis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Parthenogenesis, where a female worm can produce offspring without male fertilization, is a unique reproductive strategy seen in Strongyloides stercoralis. This worm is also oviviparous, laying eggs that hatch almost immediately.

questions.text: Casal's necklace is seen with which vitamin deficiency?(FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Niacin

 

Explanation:

 

 

Casal's necklace is a characteristic dermatitis seen in niacin (vitamin B3) deficiency, which leads to a condition called pellagra. Niacin can be synthesized from the amino acid tryptophan, with 60 mg of tryptophan converting to 1 mg of niacin daily. Tryptophan deficiency is common in maize-based diets, but the actual reason for pellagra in maize eaters is not tryptophan deficiency itself, but rather an excess of leucine, which prevents the conversion of tryptophan to niacin. Leucine is therefore known as the pellagrogenic amino acid of India.

 

Pellagra is characterized by the "4 D's": diarrhea, dermatitis, dementia, and death. The dermatitis associated with pellagra often occurs around the neck or on the extremities of the body, particularly on areas of skin that are directly exposed to sunlight. When this dermatitis occurs around the neck, it may lead to the formation of Casal's necklace.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Thiamine (vitamin B1) deficiency is not associated with Casal's necklace. Instead, it can lead to beriberi in polished rice eaters and Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome in chronic alcoholics.

 

Option C. Vitamin C deficiency is not related to Casal's necklace. It can cause scurvy, which is characterized by symptoms such as bleeding gums, easy bruising, and poor wound healing.

 

Option D. Cyanocobalamin (vitamin B12) deficiency is not linked to Casal's necklace. It can cause peripheral neuropathy, megaloblastic anemia, subacute combined degeneration of the spinal cord, and pernicious anemia, especially in strict vegetarians.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Casal's necklace is a characteristic dermatitis seen around the neck in niacin (vitamin B3) deficiency, which leads to a condition called pellagra.

choices.text: Do USG, don’t see the fetus gender and don’t tell the woman
Do USG, see the fetus gender and don’t tell the woman
Do USG, see the fetus gender and tell the woman

questions.text: G5P4 lady with 4 female children reports for the first time at 18 weeks POG. As per the PCPNDT Act and Beti Bachao Andolan, what will you do? [NEET PG 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Do USG, don’t see the fetus gender and don’t tell the woman

 

In India, the Pre-Conception and Pre-Natal Diagnostic Techniques (PCPNDT) Act, 1994, strictly prohibits the determination of fetal sex to prevent female feticide. The act is a legal measure to curb the misuse of diagnostic techniques for sex determination, which could lead to gender-selective abortions. This law aligns with the Beti Bachao Beti Padhao initiative, which aims to save and educate the girl child.

 

In the given scenario, the woman is at 18 weeks of gestation. A USG (ultrasound) scan is recommended to assess fetal health and pregnancy progress but not to determine the fetus's gender. Neither the radiologist nor the obstetrician/gynecologist should attempt to determine or disclose the fetus's gender unless there is a valid legal or medical reason, which is rare and strictly controlled.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Don’t do the USG scan: This option is incorrect because USG is an important tool for monitoring fetal development and maternal health. Refusing to perform a USG scan without medical justification would be inappropriate and neglectful of standard prenatal care.

 

Option C. Do USG, see the fetus gender and don’t tell the woman:  This option is incorrect because, under the PCPNDT Act, healthcare professionals are prohibited from determining the gender of the fetus during a USG scan unless medically indicated. Viewing the fetus's gender without a valid reason is a violation of the law.

 

Option D.  Do USG, see the fetus gender and tell the woman: This option is incorrect and illegal as per the PCPNDT Act. Disclosing the gender of the fetus to the expectant mother or any other person is punishable by law, as it could lead to gender-based discrimination and sex-selective abortions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fetal sex determination and disclosure are illegal under the PCPNDT Act unless medically indicated. During routine prenatal care, USG should be performed without determining or revealing the fetus's gender.

questions.text: Given below is the image of a 33-hour chick embryo. Which of the following is derived from the marked structure? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ribs

 

 

 

  • The marked structure in the image is the para-axial mesoderm. In the 33-hour chick embryo, the para-axial mesoderm is situated on each side of the neural tube and notochord. This mesoderm divides into segments known as somites. Somites further differentiate into sclerotome, myotome, and dermatome.
  • The sclerotome, derived from the somites, gives rise to the vertebrae and ribs. The para-axial mesoderm is responsible for forming these segmented structures, essential components of the axial skeleton.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Kidney: Incorrect. The kidney is derived from the intermediate mesoderm, not the para-axial mesoderm.

 

Option B. Dorsal root ganglion: Incorrect. The dorsal root ganglion is derived from neural crest cells, which are separate from the para-axial mesoderm.

 

Option C. Parietal pleura: Incorrect. The parietal pleura is derived from the lateral plate mesoderm, not the para-axial mesoderm.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The para-axial mesoderm forms somites, which give rise to the vertebrae and ribs.
